 104 mulera frasen i oratio recta; naturligt nog med tanke på att dialogen i kap. 13 mel- lan djävulen och ängeln i övrigt framställs genom direkta anföringar. Att cruciare verkligen ingår i en oratio obliqua framgår dock av fuisset, som av Gh mycket riktigt ändrats till fuerit. Fsv. visar på detta ställe, att den är beroende av Gh-recensionen, BU 3, 265, 31 ff. Diäfwllin suaradhe tha hawir iak än een säk fullan mz the scriptinne som han skulle haua bätrat mz sina synde thy bör mik til at han pina alt til thäs the äru alle opnöta. Orden Que quidem . . . vita sua har ej översatts. Frasen som han skulle haua bätrat mz sina synde ter sig egendomlig med tanke på ordföljden: det är naturligt att uppfatta som som objekt till haua bätrat. Med utgångspunkt från mo- dernt svenskt språkbruk hade man väntat att mz placerats sist i satsen; att låta prepositionen föregå som hade i fsv. varit lika omöjligt som i modern sv., se härom Wessen, Svensk språkhistoria2 (Lund 1965) 3,269 f. Dock framgår det av exempel hos Wessen (1.c.), att man kunnat placera prepositionen också på andra ställen än i slutet av satsen. Lunden 3, 222 översätter: »Djävulen svarade, att han ännu hade en säck full med skrifter, dvs. de botövningar, som denne riddare tänkt göra för sina synder men dock försummat. 'Därför tillkommer det mig', sade han, 'att pina honom, ända tills alla de synder blivit tillfyllestgjorda, som denne riddare icke brytt sig om att bättra i sitt liv.» Lundens »dvs. de botövningar» härrör uppenbarligen från Steffens argumentering s. 32o f., där denne vill göra gällande, att scriptinne i fsv. betyder 'botövning' och att scripturis i lat. i själva verket skulle vara en felaktig översättning av fsv.; som bekant ansåg Steffen, att fsv. var primär i förhållande till den lat. texten, en uppfattning som vederlagts av Westman 47-62 och Kraft 17-42. Steffens resonemang på just denna punkt, som av honom själv (s. 32o) betraktas som en »avgörande omständighet till förmån för den svenska textens primat», har tidigare kritiserats av Westman 55 not 4. Denna kritik kan i några viktiga avseenden kompletteras. Som redan tidigare framgått, saknar hss. motsvarighet till Jdeo teneor enligt Gh och thy bör mik til i fsv. Detta visar, att fsv. återgår på en bearbetad, av Gh företrädd textrecension. Det måste vidare fram- hållas, att sing. scriptinne i fsv. ger ett mycket egendomligt innehåll: en säck full med en botövning. Härvid är att märka, att Steffen 321 först talar om »en säck, full med den botöfning ...» för att några rader längre ner tala om »de förut omtalade botöfningarna». Då stöd för Steffens tolkning av detta ställe tycks saknas, måste Lundens översättning »dvs. de botövningar ...» tillbakavisas. Bortsett från Lundens »Därför tillkommer det mig», som återgår på Gh (eller fsv.) men saknar motsvarighet i hss., är hans översättning vidare anmärkningsvärd vad beträffar Que quidem ... in vita sua, den mening som avslutar § 39. Lundens översättning utgår från den syntaktiskt ogrundade förutsättningen, att denna sats vore en under fuisset satisfactum underordnad relativ bisats. Detta har i översätt- ningen markerats så, att peccata förts in i den föregående satsen som korrelat till que. En dylik översättning hade i latinet motsvarats av någon helt annan konstruk- tion, t. ex. pro omnibus peccatis fuisset satisfactum (eller satisfecisset), que ...; jfr 13: 55 Pro talibus satisfecit; Rev. IV zo B satisfacere deo putant pro excessibus suis; DSS V 151 f. ... ut sciam, pro quibus (sc. peccatis) satisfaciam. 
 
 
 
 
 105 I § 39 sägs två gånger, att riddaren (Birgittas son Karl) underlåtit att sona sina synder. Den fornsvenske översättaren har tydligen i denna upprepning sett en fel- aktighet och därför helt uteslutit den sista meningen i § 39. Texten torde på denna punkt tolkas så, att Birgitta genom Que quidem etc. bekräftar vad hon låtit djävulen strax tidigare påstå: Karl hade, precis som djävulen säger, underlåtit att göra bot för sina synder. Något skäl att betvivla meningens autenticitet finns knappast. 13: 40 Respondit angelus: »Aperi saccum et pete iudicium super illa peccata, pro quibus te oportet eum (0a eam ceteri Gh) castigare.» Arketypens eam syns förutsätta antingen att eam syftar på ett föresvävande animam (sc. Karoli) eller att eam är en misstolkning av ett med abbreviatur skrivet animam. Då ingen av dessa förutsättningar kan styrkas, upptas i texten läsarten eum enligt 0a. 1 den långa dialogen i kap. 13 mellan djävulen och ängeln, vilka strider om Karls själ inför domaren Kristus, förekommer det inte på något ställe, att ett feminint, på anima syftande pronomen används utan att ordet anima står tidigare i samma me- ning (§ 5) eller i närmast föregående mening (§ 6). Före § 40 används anima senast § 32, där anima f. ö. i samma mening följs av ipsum. Av de ställen, som utvisar, huruvida anima eller ett mask. begrepp (pron., miles etc.) avses, följer sedan § 33 ipso, § 38 filio, § 39 miles ... eum ... miles. Vidare kan den nämnda variationen anima ista ... ipsum i§ 32 stödjas med paralleller (§ 20 hec anima, § 24 iste; § 27 anime, § 28 ipse); som redan framgått, förekommer inte den motsatta företeelsen, dvs. att ett mask. begrepp varieras med ett fem. pron. eller med enbart anima. Vad beträffar bruket av anima i kapitlet, förekommer ordet visserligen ofta men med ett undantag endast tillsammans med någon bestämning (t. ex. §§ 9, 12, 25). Det enda undantaget är § 13, där animam står utan bestämning två gånger men där orden upprepar det i föregående mening nämnda quedam anima.9 Det är således ytterst otroligt, att eam i § 40 i själva verket skulle vara fel för animam. En återstående möjlighet att försvara arketypens eam kunde vara den, att animam trots allt måste avses, därför att § 40 handlar om den avlidne Karl. Enligt en sådan teori skulle de mask. begreppen endast användas, då den ännu levande Karl avses (t. ex. § 28 ... caritate, quam ipse habuit ...); fall som § 39 cruciare eum och § 47 ipsum punire visar dock, att ett sådant resonemang vore ohållbart. Add. 16: 37 ... habendo assistentes tales, qui timeant (Gh timeant deum F K deum timeant p q) et qui non plus diligunt mungira eius quam animam et honorem eius ... Det har tidigare i framställningen gjorts gällande, att en splittring av traditionen på tre olika läsarter, varav en lockar till emendation, kan utgöra ett indicium på att de båda övriga läsarterna är resultat av en sådan emendation; jfr s. 92 f. Denna teori tycks kunna göras tillämplig på fallet i 6: 37. Att Gh-läsarten, som i jämförelse med de övriga inbjuder till förtydligande, varit arketypens, stöds inte bara av att 9 Ett skenbart undantag utgör § 27 anime: här har eius eller sue ej behövt utsättas på grund av sui i det omedelbart föregående corporis sui. 
 
 
 
 
 io6 traditionen uppvisar tre olika läsarter utan dessutom av att läsarterna ej fördelar sig i hss. så, som man skulle ha väntat med utgångspunkt från stemmat. I själva verket torde man på fyra olika punkter ha gjort tillägget deum. Detta kan synas mycket, men å andra sidan måste man ha klart för sig, att tillägget deum är ytterst lättförklarligt vid verbet timere; härtill kommer, att ett timere deum (eller deum timere) i arketypen förutsätter avvikelser på så pass mycket som tre ställen. Läsarten timeant i arketypen kan försvaras. Ett utsatt deum gör, att syftningen eius, som ju avser puer (dvs. den cypriotiske kungen), framstår som mindre klar; det är tvärtom lika tänkbart, att ett på kungen syftande eum föresvävar som objekt vid timeant. Men å andra sidan är det tveksamt, om överhuvud något objekt behöver suppleras vid timeant. En absolut användning av timere föreligger i i: 21 Timeat iam et sic vivat ..., Lunden 3, 215 »Hon må alltså hysa fruktan och leva så ...» Denna användning kan jämföras med i i: 9 habeat continuum timorem in corde, Lunden 3, 214 »må hon beständigt känna fruktan i sitt hjärta», dvs. utan utsatt obj. gen. till timorem. diligunt, jfr Rev. II 29 B homo ... Vad beträffar modusväxlingen timeant quam artus et vilis sit nidus corporis, quam lucida sunt10 addiscit cogitare celestia et quam delectabilia sunt eterna. 18: 7 vt status ipsorum totaliter reformotur (C k J e reformentur ceteri Gh) Med tanke på § 6 a sancto statu priorum sanctorum patrum och pristinum statum suorum predecessorum syns det berättigat att också i § 7 status se en singularform, varför läsarten enligt C k J e upptas i texten. Huruvida arketypen haft reformentur är svårt att uttala sig om; då variationen endast berörs av linea nasalis, kan läsarten reformentur givetvis tänkas ha uppstått i p och n oberoende av varandra. corrigatur (1 0a k Gh corrigantur 18: 15 ... vt tulium obstinatorum proteruitas ceteri). Syntaxen kräver här corrigatur; för bedömningen av felet corrigantur, jfr före- gående fallet. vmbilicum eius, qui statim abscisus est, nec inde aliquis liquor (p, Gh liuor 21: 17 ceteri) aut sanguis exiuit. Samstämmigheten mellan p, och n visar, att arketypen läst liuor. Jag har icke kun- nat belägga någon betydelse av liuor, som kunde motivera ordet här. Liksom i klat. betyder liuor i mlat. 'blånad', 'blåmärke' och, i överförd bet., 'avund' (jfr Novum Glossarium s. v.). Samordningen med sanguis och predikatet exiuit gör emenda- tionen liquor naturlig och denna läsart upptas i editionen som den rätta. Läsarten liuor torde icke kunna frånkännas ett visst bindande värde och styrker tanken, att original och arketyp ej är identiska. " Av de undersökta källorna Gh, P, q och Cod. Urb. Lat. 104 (Vatikanen) finns detta sunt med endast i Gh och q. 
 
 
 
 
 I07 22: I >>Filia mea, diu est quod ego (X w x ante diu trp. p, n K q om. p2 F Gh) promiseram tibi .>> Det är föga troligt, att pi, n resp. K q oberoende av varandra kunnat placera ego framför diu, vilket pekar på att deras läsart också varit arketypens. Någon parallell, som kunde stödja denna egendomliga ordföljd, har jag inte funnitll och utgår därför från att ego visserligen funnits i originalet men i arketypen fått en felaktig placering; tanken att arketypen saknat ego motsägs av att det inte finns något skäl att lägga till ordet. I editionen upptas den emendation, som gjorts i den för X w x gemensamma källan. Utelämningen i p, F Gh torde f. ö. också vara att betrakta som emendation. Fallet tillhör således samma kategori som 16: 37; se ovan. 27: 22 0 inimici mei, qui talia facitis et alla peccata mee voluntati contraria ef- fr onte<r> (scripsi efronte r in marg. Y2 XnPeffronteBEwxFKqGh effrenate r-Ckm0a) committitis, quare neglexistis passionem meam ...? Arketypen har haft effronte eller efronte. Det ligger här närmast till hands att räkna med en form av effrons, som i flera lexika (t. ex. Bartal, Du Cange, Latham, Sleumer) beläggs i betydelsen 'skamlös'; stavningen efrons finns dessutom noterad hos Diefenbach. Från innehållssynpunkt passar ordet bra in i sammanhanget (»skamlöst begår ni synder mot min vilja»),12 men endast under förutsättningen att det har en form som adverb eller som adjektiv i plur. (pred. attrib.). Formen effronte enligt arketypen faller inte, om ordet effrons ligger till grund, inom någon av dessa kategorier. Utifrån samma förutsättning syns därför effronte vara ett arke- typfel. En näraliggande emendation är då effronte<r>, som finns noterat hos bl. a. Du Cange och Latham. Från paleografisk synpunkt vore en sådan felaktighet för- klarlig: effronte kan sålunda ha uppkommit genom att en abbreviatur för -er miss- tolkats. Emellertid finns hos Diefenbach en notis, som onekligen talar för att effronte trots allt kan vara det rätta. Diefenbach förtecknar nämligen ordet ef- frontus, lämnar dock ingen översättning utan hänvisar till effrondatus. Under effrondatus uppges som variant effrontus, men någon upplysning om beläggsställe lämnas inte. För effrondatus ger Diefenbach översättningen 'verschempter' och hänvisar till Joh. Melber de Geroltzhoffens Variloquus13 ( =Vocabularius prae- dicantium), som förtecknar ordet i samma betydelse som hos Diefenbach. För va- rianten effrontus anges, som redan påpekats, inget beläggsställe men däremot jäm- förs med effrondare, för vilket Diefenbach hänvisar till Glossarium manuale ad scriptores mediae et infimae latinitatis. Halae 1782. 80. ( = Ducangii Glossarium ab Adelungio retractatum). Detta arbete är av allt att döma identiskt med Glossarium manuale ad scriptores mediae et infimae latinitatis ex magnis glossariis ... Halae 1772-84. 14 r , detta lexikon upptas visserligen effrondare men med tillägget »pro effondrare ------ demergere».15 Diefenbachs hänvisning till detta effrondare är svår att förstå; under alla förhållanden kastar den inget ljus över den av Diefenbach noterade varianten effrontus till effrondatus. Utifrån Diefenbachs notis om effrontus kan den rätta lösningen av problemet 27:22 vara att i effronte se ett adverb av detta adjektiv. Då det ej varit möjligt att närmare granska detta effrontus, syns det dock motiverat att tills vidare betrakta effronte som möjligen rätt läsart; i editionen upptas den ovan nämnda emendationen effronte<r>. 28: 7 Illi vero, qui contempnunt predicta filii mei et mea sustentacula spiritualia et inclinantur a vento temptacionum per dy aboli consensum (scripsi per dyabolicum sensum pi B C m Oa per dyabolicum consensum E k dyaboli consensu n Gh) et op er e (opera L opus r), ipsi eradicantur a statu gracie et ducuntur a dyabolo per illicita desideria et opera vsque ad profundas eternales genas et tenebras infernorum. Det är uppenbart, att p-hyparketypens läsart här varit per dyabolicum sensum. Denna läsart måste dock vara en förvanskning av per dyaboli consensum och har uppkommit genom att con- uppfattats som cum och felaktigt lagts till dyaboli. Det är nämligen ganska tydligt, att originalet haft en form av consensus för att korrespon- dera med det följande opere, 'samtycke och handling'. Som stödjande paralleller kan nämnas Rev. II 6 B ... affectum et consensum superbie dederunt ... affectum op er e compleuerunt; VIII 48 L demon animam trahit ad se forcipe praue delecta- tionis dissoluitque eam malleo, idest consensu et p er petr atione delictorum. Också 28: 7 desideria et opera är att föra till denna uttryckstyp, där begreppen 'vilja' och 'handling' kombineras. Originalet har haft antingen per dyaboli consensum eller dyaboli consensu; teore- tiskt tänkbart är också alternativet dyabolico <con)sensu. Var och en av dessa möj- ligheter skall nedan prövas närmare. Om dyaboli är rätt, skall det ej uppfattas som possessiv genitiv till consensu(m): det är människorna, som dels ger sitt samtycke, dvs, faller för frestelserna, dels i handling begår synderna. De ovan lämnade exemplen styrker denna uppfattning (Rev. II 6 B; VIII 48 L). 'Med någons samtycke' heter f. ö. i mlat. vanligen de (mer sällan cum) consensu alcis, t. ex. Ex. 69: 4 (cum); SA i i E (de); A &P 423, 425 (de); Kat. proc. 74 (två fall med de). Man har således i dyaboli att se antingen en objektiv genitiv till consensu(m) eller en possessiv genitiv till temptacionum. Den senare möjligheten, som dock inte ges av f3, har utnyttjats i fsv., BU 3, 292, 24 f. böghias aff diäfulsins fr estils a swärdhe mz villa ok gerningom; jag går ej här när- 14 Namnet Adelung saknas således, men enligt uppgift från Kungl.  109 mare in på den besynnerliga felöversättningen swärdhe för vento. En sådan tolkning ger ett gott innehåll men å andra sidan kan man inte göra gällande, att temptacionum här med nödvändighet måste ha någon bestämning; texten låter sig förstås i alla fall, jfr Lunden 3, 247 »Men de, som försmå min Sons och mitt andliga stöd och av frestelsernas vind låta böja sig till att samtycka till djävulen i vilja och gärning, ...» Lunden ser således i dyaboli en objektiv genitiv till consensu (så i Gh, Lundens för- laga). En sådan är nödvändig, då det gäller per dyaboli consensum och möjlig, då det gäller dyaboli consensu. Någon parallell till just kombinationen dyaboli consensus har jag inte funnit. Emellertid kan uttrycket knappast sägas vara egendomligt och kom- mer i själva verket ytterst nära fraser som Thomas Aquinas, Summa contra Gen- tiles 3, 158 per delectationem tracta fuit voluntas ad consensum peccati; 16 Ma- gister Mathias, Homo conditus, Cod. Ups. C 217 fol. 20ra ... per que se ipsum homo ... in temptacionem et consensum mali precipitet. Även i det ovan lämnade fallet Rev. VIII 48 L syns det berättigat att i delictorum se en bestämning också till con- sensu. Härtill kommer att frasen consentire dyabolo icke är så ovanlig; ur revela- tionerna kan nämnas I i B; I 26 C; dessutom SA 6 C hostili suggestori (=dyabolo) consentiens. I frågan huruvida dyaboli skall fattas som objektiv genitiv till con- sensu(m) eller som poss. genitiv till temptacionum kan således något utslag inte gärna baseras på språkliga och innehållsliga fakta. Vid en jämförande bedömning av läsarterna per dyaboli consensum och dyaboli consensu bortses därför från detta problem. I stället kan det konstateras, att medan den senare läsarten ej på något sätt är anmärkningsvärd, förhåller det sig annor- lunda med per dyaboli consensum,17 som ju tillsammans med det följande opere företer en påfallande inkoncinnitet. Denna har observerats i e och där föranlett emendationen opus (opera L). Den konstruktionsväxling, som föreligger, kan dock stödjas, jfr Rev. IV 76 non propter fauorem ... seu cupiditatem ... sed amor e solius dei. Utifrån förutsättningen att per dyaboli consensum är den rätta läsarten, till- kommer den viktiga omständigheten, att ett kongruent uttryckssätt här hade varit omöjligt: frasen per ... opus enligt e går ej att belägga. Däremot finns ett stort antal paralleller till opere, av vilka somliga tycks peka på att opere stelnat och betraktats som ett adverb. Påfallande är detta i frasen opere facere, t. ex. Rev. II 27 C Deinde (sc. debet vir bonus istos malos homines excolere) opere faciendo bona que poterit; IV 143 A Faciat ergo opere que honoris mei sunt; VI 45 D hoc etiam opere per- fecit; VI 85 (ex.) Sed nec illi amittunt celum, qui voluntatem perfectissimam habent restituendi (sc. male acquisita) et faciunt oper e quantum possunt. De komplikatio- ner, som utmärker läsarten per dyaboli consensum, behöver således inte utesluta, att den varit originalets. Den tredje tänkbara läsarten, dyabolico <con)sensu (med dyabolico syftande på vento), stöds av § 5 dyabolico temptacionum vento samt § 6 dyabolico temptacionum 16 Texten citerad efter S. Thomae de Aquino ... Summa contra Gentiles. Editio Leonina manua- lis. Romae 1 934, s. 419. 17 Vad beträffar själva frasen per consensum i detta sammanhang, jfr Magister Mathias, Homo conditus, Cod. Ups. C 217 fol. 20vb dyabolo conscienciam per consensum aperuit. 
 
 
 
 
 I I 0 incursu och den ger ett acceptabelt innehåll. För en bedömning av läsarten är det dock nödvändigt att ställa den i relation till de båda övriga i ljuset av en allmän stemmatisk-principiell analys av textstället. Den tidigare behandlingen av fallet har vilat på förutsättningen, att originalet haft en av tre föreslagna läsarter. Då det gäller frågan om vad som stått i arketypen, är det principiellt nödvändigt att räkna med att också f3-läsarten per dyabolicum sensum kan ha varit dess läsart. Den följande utredningen utgår från att p- läsarten utvecklats ur per dyaboli consensum och ej ur dyaboli consensu; utifrån för- utsättningen, att dyaboli consensu varit arketypens läsart, är det givetvis föga troligt, att f3-läsarten uppkommit genom att först con- överflyttats som -cum till dyaboli, eftersom per, som då skall ha tillagts senare, inte på något sätt gör texten tydligare. Tanken att det stått dyaboli consensu i arketypen motsägs av att det ej funnits vare sig språkliga eller innehållsliga skäl att frångå denna läsart till förmån för per dyaboli consensum. Denna teori innefattar vidare förutsättningen, att man på ytterligare en punkt frångått den traderade texten, nämligen vid p-felets uppkomst; det har ju ovan hävdats, att per dyabolicum sensum förutsätter ett per dyaboli consensum tidi- gare i traditionen. Ett per dyaboli consensum i arketypen innebär dels att n gjort en emendation, betingad av strävan efter koncinnitet, dels att p-hyparketypens skri- vare felaktigt fört con- till dyaboli i form av ändelsen -cum. Detta senare alternativ är principiellt sett mer sannolikt än det första: båda teorierna inbegriper avvikelse från den traderade texten på två punkter, men medan det i det första alternativet ej funnits motiv för någon av avvikelserna, kan en av avvikelserna i det senare alterna- tivet ges en rimlig motivering. Läsarten dyabolico <con>sensu blir enligt samma re- sonemang mindre sannolik, då den förutsätter ändringar på tre ställen, i samtliga fall helt omotiverade. Den sista möjligheten, nämligen att arketypen haft läsarten per dyabolicum sensum syns vara den mest tilltalande, då den förutsätter avvikelse från den traderade texten på endast en punkt, nämligen en emendation i n, som det dessutom funnits skäl att göra. Korrigeringen till consensu kan knappast sägas vara osannolikt avancerad: faktiskt har också E och k oberoende av varandra kommit fram till att ordet consensus är nödvändigt i sammanhanget. En analys av handskriftsläget gör det således mest sannolikt, att arketypen haft läsarten per dyabolicum sensum, vilken bevarats i p men emenderats i n. Eftersom, det från språklig eller innehållsmässig synpunkt ej går att klart hävda den ena läs- arten framför den andra, väljes därför p-läsarten, emenderad på det sätt innehållet kräver; förfarandet har därtill stöd av den i kapitlet om editionsprinciper framlagda allmänna värderingen av p.

Cap. II. In purificacione beate Marie virginis, dum esset domina Birgitta 5 Christi sponsa in Roma in ecclesia, que dicitur Sancte Marie Maioris, rapta fuit dicta domina in spiritualem visionem, videns in celo quasi omnia ad magnum festum preparari. 2 Et tunc vidit quasi vnum temp- lum mirabilis pulchritudinis et ibi erat ille venerabilis senex iustus Symeon paratus ad recipiendum puerum Ihesum in vinis suis cum 0 summo desiderio et gaudio. 3 Videbat quoque beatam virginem ho- nestissime incedentem et portantem puerum filium, vt offerret eum in templo secundum legem Domini; deinde innumerabilem multitudinem angelorum et diuersorum ordinum sanctorum Dei et sanctarum virgi- num et dominarum beatam virginem matrem Dei precedencium et eam .5 cum omni leticia et deuocione circumdancium. 4 Ante quam portabatur a quodam angelo vnus gladius longus et valde latus et sanguinolentus, qui significabat illos maximos dolores, quos Maria passa est in morte amantissimi filii sui, qui figurabantur in gladio, quem iustus Symeon §§ 2-4 cfr Luc. 2, 25-35 II: p 7, (exc.  116 20 5 LIBRI SEPTIMI CAP. 2-3 prophetabat ipsius animam pertransiturum esse. 5 Vnde tota exultante celesti curia dictum fuit sponse: »Ecce quantus honor et gloria rependi- tur in hoc festo regine celi pro gladio dolorum, quos sustinuit in sui dilecti filii passione.» Et tunc hec visin disparuit. Reuelacio, quam beatus Franciscus ostendit domine Birgitte, in qua inuitauit eam ad cameram suam ad comedendum et bibendum, declarans ei spiritua- liter, quod camera fuit obediencia, cibus eius fuit conuertere animas ad Deum, potus autem erat, quando conuersos videbat totis viribus Deum diligere et oracioni aliisque virtutibus cum feruore vacare. Cap. III. In festo sancti Francisci in sua ecclesia Rome in Transtiberim appa- ruit sanctus Franciscus eidem sponse Christi dicens: »Veni in cameram meam ad comedendum et bibendum mecum.» Quod ipsa audiens statim parauit se ad iter, vt visitaret eum in Assisio. 2 Vbi dum per quinque .0 dies moram duxisset, proponens tunc Romam redire, intrauit ecclesiam, vt se et suos sancto Francisco commendaret. 3 Cui tunc ipse apparuit dicens: »Bene veneris!  I 18 5 LIBRI SEPTIMI CAP. 4 Hanc reuelacionem habuit domina Birgitta in ciuitate Ortone regni Nea- polis. Cui Christus loquens certificat eam, quod ibi sunt reliquie corporis sancti Thome apostoli in altari, in quibus reliquiis et alforum sanctorum suorum ipse delectatur suauissime, reputans eas suum preciosum thesaurum in terra, promittens magnum meritum et premium eas venerantibus cum deuocione debita. Cap. IV. Vni persone vigilanti in oracione videbatur, quod quasi cor suum esset ardens diuina caritate et totum plenum gaudio spirituali, quo ipsum corpus quasi deficiebat a viribus suis. Tunc audiuit vocem dicentem sibi: io 2 »Ego sum creator omnium et redemptor. Scito igitur, quod tale gaudium, quale nunc sentis in anima tua, talis est thesaurus meus, quia, sicut scriptum est, 'Spiritus vbi vult spirat et vocem eius audis, sed nescis vnde veniat aut quo vadat'.3 Istumautemthesaurum tribuo ego amicis meis multipharie multisque modis et multis donis. is Verumptamen dicere tibi volo de alio thesauro, qui nondum est in celis sed est vobiscum in terra. 4 Hic thesaurus est reliquie et corpora ami- corum meorum. Nam vere corpora sanctorum meorum, siue putrida sint vel recencia, siue conuersa sint in cinerem et puluerem siue non, ipsa sunt certissime thesaurus meus. 5 Sed querere poteris: Cum loquitur 20 Scriptura 'Vbi est thesaurus tuus, ibi est cor tuum', quomodo 12 20 sq. Ideo cor meum est cum thesauro meo. 7 Propterea scire te volo pro certissimo, quod in isto loco est thesaurus meus electissimus, scilicet reliquie sancti Thome apostoli mei, que in nullo loco sunt ita multe sicut in isto altari incorrupte et indiuise. 8 Nam cum illa ciuitas vastata 3o esset, vbi primo corpus apostoli mei depositum fuit, tunc translatus est iste thesaurus permissione mea per quosdam amicos meos in hane ciui- tatem et positus in altari isto. 9 Nunc autem iacet hic quasi occultus, quia principes huius terre, antequam corpus apostoli huc veniret, erant dispositi sicut scriptum est: _ro 'Os habent et non loquentur, ocu- 35 los habent et non videbunt.  LIBRI SEPTIMI CAP. 5 7 131 In Roma, antequam domina Birgitta iret ultra mare, quidam frater minor deuotus consuluit dictam dominam super aliquibus dubiis sue consciencie. Cui domine oranti virgo Maria apparuit, raspondens ei ad illa dubia plenarie, et insuper dicit, quod, quantumcumque papa et presbiteri sint peccatores, dum tamen non sint heretici, quod ille habet claues Ecclesie et veram potestatem ligandi et soluendi et isti plene conficiunt et pertractant benedictum sacramentum corporis Christi in altari, quamuis sint indigni celesti gloria. Cap. VII. Ad honorem et graciarum accionem reddendum Deo omnipotenti et 50 beate Marie virgini, sue dignissime matri. Michi indigne persone ora- cioni vacanti videbatur, quod mater Dei michi peccatrici loqueretur hec subsequencia verba: »Dic illi fratri amico meo, qui per te supplicacionem suam michi transmisit, quod vera fides est et perfecta veritas, quod, si aliqua persona 55 instigante dyabolo contra Deum omnia peccata commisisset, que postea cum vera contricione et voluntate emendandi veraciter peniteret et hu- militer cum ardenti caritate a Deo misericordiam postularet, 3 nullum dubium est, quod statim ipse benignus et misericors Deus ita paratus esset ad recipiendum illam personam in graciam suam cum magno 20 gaudio et leticia sicut pater caritatiuus, qui videret vnicum filium suum dilectissimum ad se redeuntem, iam liberatum de maximo scandalo et turpissima morte. 4 Et vere multo libencius ipse pius Deus quam aliquis pater carnalis omnia peccata dimittit seruitoribus suis, qui assidue peni- 1-66 cfr A&P p. 382; Klockars p. 206 VII: p n (exc.  132 LIBRI SEPTIMI CAP. 7 tent et ab eo humiliter misericordiam postulant et peccata vlterius com- mittere pertimescunt atque Dei amiciciam super omnia toto cordis 25 desiderio concupiscunt. 5 Igitur dic eidem fratri ex parte mea, quod propter suam bonam voluntatem et meam oracionem ex Dei bonitate omnia sunt iam sibi indulta sua peccata, que ipse commisit omnibus diebus vite sue. 6 Dic 3 0 eciam illi, quod propter oracionem meam caritas, quam ipse habet ad Deum, semper ei augmentabitur vsque ad suam mortem et nullatenus diminuetur. 7 Item dic ei, quod placet Deo filio meo, quod ipse in Roma permaneat predicando, petentibus bona consilia dando, confes- siones audiendo et salutares penitencias iniungendo, nisi prelatus suus 35 propter aliquam necessitatem legittimam ipsum aliquando miserit extra vrbem. 8 Arguat eciam idem frater alios fratres suos caritatiue pro transgressionibus suis cum honis verbis et salutaribus disciplinis et eciam cum lustis correpcionibus, vbi corrigere poterit, ad hoc vt ipsi regulam seruent et se humiliter emendent. 9 Preterea notifico ei, quod 4 0 misse ipsius et lectura atque oraciones Deo sunt acceptabiles et grate.  140 75 LIBRI SEPTIMI CAP. I 0—I I suam anima eius proiceretur in inferno perpetuo crucianda, vt ibidem fieret cibus demonum eternaliter sine fine. zo Ymmo eciam si sanctus Gregorius papa hoc statuisset, numquam in predicta sentencia miseri- cordiam optinuisset a Deo, nisi ante mortem suam humiliter reuocasset.>> Hic est principium cuiusdam reuelacionis, quam domina Birgitta habuit pro domina regina Neapolitana in eadem ciuitate, sed alfa, que ibi continentur, non ponuntur hic, quia secreta sunt, que pertinent ad statum et personam dicte domine regine. Cap. XI. »Ego sum Deus, creator omnium. Ego dedi angelis et hominibus A liberum arbitrium, vt qui vellent facere voluntatem meam, manerent mecum eternaliter, qui vero contraria michi sentirent, a me sequestra- rentur. Cap. XII.  170 LIBRI SEPTIMI CAP. 16 9 De confessore ducis. Christus loquitur: »Quid tibi dixit frater ille? 3 0 Nonne quia dux bonus est et melius viuere non potest, excusans in- continenciam eius? ro Tales non sunt confessores sed deceptores, qui vadunt tamquam oues simplices sed verius sunt vulpes et adulatores. Tales sunt amici illi, qui vident et proponunt hominibus assumpciones et deiecciones propter modicum temporale. 11 Ideo si iste frater sedisset 35 in conuentu, minus optinuisset supplicium et maiorem coronam. Nunc autem non effugiet manum increpantis et tribulantis.» 12 Quidam consuluerunt domine mutare vestes et denigrare facies propter Saracenos. Christus loquitur: »Quid consulunt tibi? Nonne deformare vestes et denigrare facies? 13 Numquid ego Deus, qui precipio tibi, 4 0 ne sim sicut ille, qui ignorat futura, aut sicut impotens, qui omnia formidat? Nequaquam. 1 4 Sed ego ipsa sapiencia, ipsa potencia, qui et omnia prescio et omnia possum.  LIBRI SEPTIMI CAP. 17-18 5 173 Cum domina Birgitta existens in Iherusalem dubitaret, vtrum melius esset, quod ipsa hospitaretur in monasterio fratrum minorum montis Syon vel vt- rum in hospitali peregrinorum in Iherusalem, et tunc in oracione apparuit ei virgo Maria dicens ei, quod in hospitali propter bonum exemplum aliorum. Cap. XVII. Mater Dei loquitur: »In isto loco montis Syon sunt duo genera ho- minum. Aliqui diligunt Deum toto corde; alii volunt habere Deum, sed mundus dulcior est eis quam Deus. 2 Et ideo, ne scandalizentur boni et ne detur occasio tepidis et futuris exemplum, ideo melius est residere in ° loco peregrinis deputato. Filius enim meus prouidebit vobis de omnibus, sicut sibi placet.» 5 Domina Birgitta rogata in regno Cypri a domina Elionor, regina dicti regnni, quod ipsa rogaret Deum pro filio suo rege et pro illo regno, transiuit tunc in Iherusalem et ibi quadam die illa existente in oracione Christus apparuit ei et dixit ei ista consilia, que deberet scribere dicto regi et patruo suo, principi Antiochie. Et precepit ei, quod scriberet ea illis quasi a se et non ex parte Christi. Cap. XVIII.  1 74 LIBRI SEPTIMI CAP. 18 puram et plenariam confessionem faciat de omnibus, que commisit I° contra Dei voluntatem, et sic recipiatis benedictum corpus Domini nostri Ihesu Christi cum timore et caritate Dei. 2 Secundum consilium est, quod ambo sitis vniti in vero amore, ita quod sitis cor vnum ad Deum et honorem eius, regendo regnum ad Dei honorem et subditorum vtilitatem. 3 Tercium consilium est, quod ambo sitis vniti in vera cari- 15 tate cum subditis vestris, indulgendo et parcendo solummodo propter reuerenciam passionis et mortis Ihesu Christi omnibus, qui consilio, facto vel fauore dederunt operam in morte patris vestri, regis Petri, 4 ac- cipiendo illos toto corde in vestram caritatem ad hoc, vt Deus in suam misericordiam recipere vos dignetur ac eciam vt ipse ad regendum 20 regnum velit vos roborare ad sui honorem. 5 Quartum consilium est, quod, ex quo diuina prouidencia vos constituit gubernatores regni, ad- hibeatis omnem diligenciam, quam poteritis, in colloquendo et effica- efter caritatiuo animo consulendo omnibus prelatis, tam ecclesiarum quam religionum, 6 quod omnes ipsi et eorum subditi se corrigant in 25 omnibus, in quibus a sancto statu priorum sanctorum patrum, suorum predecessorum, quomodolibet deuiauerunt spiritualiter vel temporaliter, et ad viuendum pure in pristinum statum suorum predecessorum cele- riter se reducant, 7 vt status ipsorum totaliter reformetur, vt sic ipsi et eorum subditi veraciter emendati optineant amiciciam Dei et digni 3 0 efficiantur ad rogandum Deum, quod ipse dignetur statum vniuersalis Ecclesie in sanctitate virtutum misericorditer renouare. 8 Quintum B consilium est, quod propter illam caritatem magnam, qua Deus dilexit animas vestras, vos velitis diligere animas subditorum vestrorum, 9 9 puram et plenariam] plenam et puram K puram J e i o benedictum om.  191 LIBRI SEPTIMI CAP. 22-23 1 5 ipsi attendebant ad illud, quod non poterant inter eos mirabilia Dei diuulgari. 6 Et ideo scias veraciter, quod, quamuis homines secundum humanum sensum conantur asserere, quod filius meus nascebatur per modum communem, verius tamen est et absque dubio aliquo, quod ipse natus est, sicut ego dixi alias tibi et sicut nunc tu vidisti.» Fuit ad presepe Domini hec reuelacio facta eidem domine in Bethleem, qualiter pastores venerunt ad presepe ad adorandum Christum natum.  196 LIBRI SEPTIMI CAP. 27 Quando domina Birgitta in reuersione de Iherusalem transiuit per ciuitatem Neapolis, requisita per dominam reginam et archiepiscopum dicte ciuitatis orauit Deum pro habitatoribus eiusdem ciuitatis. Et Christus loquens ei redarguit habitatores predictos de pluribus peccatis, ostendens eis modum, 5 quo se reconcilient cum eo peccatores, gromittens eis misericordiam, si se reconciliauerint et emendauerint. Comminatur eciam eos cum seueritate iusticie, si se non correxerint et in peccato perseuerauerint. Quam reuelacio- nem ipsa domina Birgitta publicauit in presencia dicti domini Bernardi archiepiscopi et trium magistrorum in theologia et duorum doctorum in iure lo canonico et ciuili et aliquorum militum et ciuium dicte ciuitatis.  198 LIBRI SEPTIMI CAP. 27 Vere ipsi contempnunt precepta mea, eiciunt me de cordibus suis tamquam virus abhominabile, expuunt eciam me de ore ipsorum velut 45 rem putridam, et abhorrent me videre quasi leprosum pessime fetentem. 12 Dyabolum vero et eius opera amplectuntur toto suo affectu et opere. Hunc enim introducunt in cordibus suis, faciendo delectabiliter et gra- tanter eius voluntatem et sequendo eius immissiones malignas. 13 Ideo iusto iudicio meo remunerabuntur in inferno cum dyabolo eternaliter 5 0 sine fine. Nam pro superbia, quam exercent, habebunt confusionem et eternum pudorem in tantum, quod angeli et demones de eis dicent: 'Impleti sunt confusione vsque ad summum.' /4 Pro cupiditate vero ipsorum insaciabili quilibet dyabolus inferni replebit eos suo veneno mortifero in tantum, quod in animabus ipsorum nullus vacuus locus 55 remanebit, qui non sit dyabolico veneno repletus. /5 Pro luxuria vero, qua ardent sicut animalia insensata, numquam admittentur ad videndum faciem meam, sed separabuntur a me et privabuntur eciam sua volun- tate inordinata. /6 Ceterum scias, quod, sicut omnia peccata mortalia grauissima sunt, 6o ita eciam peccatum veniale, si homo delectatur in eo cum voluntate perseuerandi, efficitur mortale. r7 Propterea noueris, quod duo peccata exercentur, que ego nomino tibi modo, que trahunt secum alia peccata, que omnia videntur quasi venialia, sed quia gentes delectantur in eis cum voluntate perseuerandi, ideo efficiuntur mortalia.  Glossarium Glossariet har sammanställts för att på vissa punkter söka underlätta tolkningen av texten; däremot syftar det inte till att ge någon uttömmande redovisning av skillnader mellan det klassiskt latinska och det i editionen företrädda språkbruket. För stoff av syntaktisk och stilistisk natur, se Index rerum et locutionum s. 223 f. Principen vid ordurvalet har varit att i första hand taga med samtliga de ord, som saknas i Georges' Handwörterbuch. Därutöver rymmer glossariet ett antal ord, som hos Georges anförs i annan betydelse än den i texten tillämpliga. Full- ständighet har i detta senare fall ej eftersträvats, då uppgifterna hos Georges ofta är tillräckliga för att möjliggöra en riktig tolkning. Vid flertalet uppslagsord lämnas åtminstone någon hänvisning till lexikalisk eller annan litteratur. Utöver de förkortningar som meddelats i litteraturförteckningen har följande härvid kommit till användning: Ai =Arnaldi, Be = Blaise, Bl = Bartal, DuC = Du Cange, Hm = Hammarström, Hs = Hakamies, Lm = Latham, MW = Mittellat. Wörterbuch, NG1 = Novum Glossarium, N-H = Nyrin-Heuman, Nr = Niermeyer, Slr = Sleumer, Sr = Souter. Hänvisningarna till Cavallin, Gertz, Hollm. och Undh. avser indices resp. glossarier till dessa forskares i litt.-förteckn. angivna editioner. abextra adv., 'utifrån', 'från utsidan' 21: i. (Cfr Hollm.) accidiosus adi., i.q. acediosus, 'håglös', 'trög' 5: 38. (Hollm. s.v. accidia.) ad minus adv. = saltem, 'åtminstone' 12: 14. Reg. Salv. 16; A&P 65 (med.). (Hm s.v. minus. Cfr Gall. au moins, It. almeno.) archiepiscopatus, us m., 'ärkebiskopsäm- bete' 12: i i. (Be.) beatus adi. = sanctus, 'helig' 3:R; passim. (Hm.) beneficiatus, i m. = qui habet beneficium ('kyrkligt gäll') i z: 14; 29: 5. (Hs, MW.) camera, e f., 'rum' passim. (Undh.) capella, e f. =sacellum, 'kapell' 15:R; 24:R. (Hollm.) caritatiue adv. = pie, cum caritate, 'kärleks- fullt' 7: 8; io: 2; 13: 77. (Hollm. s.v. caritatiuus, Hs.) caritatiuus adi. = caritate plenus, 'kärleks- full' 7: 3; 13: 6o; 18: 5. (Hollm., Hs.) celebrare v. = missam agere, 'förrätta mässa' 8:R. DSS VI 17o. (Hollm., Hs.) comitissa, e f., 'grevinna' 5:R. (Hm 2. Cfr Gall. comtesse, It. contessa.) communicare v., 'begå nattvarden' 27: 35. A&P 8o (ex.) (pass.); DSS III 153 sqq. (ter).  Index rerum et locutionum Denna index upptar dels sådant som behandlas i editionens inledning (sidhänvisningar med vanliga siffror), dels företeelser av främst syntaktiskt och stilistiskt intresse hämtade direkt ur editionen (kursiverade siffror anger kapitel och paragraf). Det är i båda fallen fråga om ett urval.  Summary On various occasions, the last being immediately before her death (cf. Rev. VII 31: 6), St. Birgitta (1303-73) entrusted to the Spaniard, Alphonso, previously Bishop of Jaen, the task of editing her Revelations. Alphonso laid the result of his work, a first edition of the Revelations, before the Commission appointed by Pope Gregory XI, during the proceedings, which were undertaken in 1377, to canonise Birgitta. Because of the Great Schism the canonisation proceedings were broken off without any decision being reached in 1380. The Prior of Alvastra, Petrus Olavi, who had been Birgitta's chief secretary and father confessor, returned to Sweden that same year and handed over a large collection of Birgittine texts to Vadstena Convent. In addition to the texts which Petrus brought home from Italy and which included revelations which Alphonso omitted from his edition for reasons of church policy, this collection contained material which was never at the latter's disposal, being copies of revelations occurring during St. Birgitta's stay in Sweden. Petrus had deposited these in Alvastra Convent before St. Birgitta's departure for Rome in 1349. Some parts of this material were included as supplements to the Alphonso edition during the 138o's. At the time of St. Birgitta's canonisation (1391) manuscripts were probably in existence incorporating among the additional material the supplements in Book 7 (Addiciones after Chapters 4, 5, i i and 16) which are of special interest for this thesis. There were various attempts during the i5th century to edit the remainder of Petrus' material until the definitive order was established in the first printed version of the Revelations, the Ghotan edition (Gh) of 1492. On the whole we may say that the material which Alphonso omitted from his edition, or was not available to him, was included in the Books of Revelations as we encounter them in the Ghotan edition. This edition was later followed by 8 different issues, the last being from 1680. Of Birgitta's visions only the Reuela- ciones Extrauagantes have so far been published in a modern critical edition by L. Hollman (Uppsala 1956). This thesis gives the Seventh Book of St. Birgitta's Revelations in a critical edition, based on the manuscript material. In the introductory section 45 manu- scripts are presented, classified and evaluated. In the first group of manuscripts to be discussed, designated y (TXZEafntwxz),Eaft are all shown to be copies of an extant manuscript, T, and are therefore eliminated. Even T is regarded as unnecessary for the reconstruction of the text, as are the less accurate mss. Z z; the -hyp ar chetyp e is reconstructed with the help of both n and X w x which are shown to represent the two branches of the y-recension (pp. 22-32). The next class of manuscripts to be discussed, p (BCEHIJLOVY0a d e k m o r), falls into two groups, designated /31 and p, respectively. A special interest is devoted to the 131-ms. r. Evidently this manuscript has drawn on material 
 
 
 
 
 226 from more than one source, and the secondary source may have been identical with Bishop Alphonso's own copies of the Revelations. The mss. H V d are rejected since the source is in all cases preserved. There is a sub-group in the p-group, designated E; one of these manuscripts, o, is regarded as worthless for the recon- struction of the e-hyparchetype and is therefore not taken into consideration in the edition (cf. pp. 33-51). The following chapter (pp. 52-69) contains a scrutiny of four manuscripts (N P Ca P), which have no supplementary material, and i i manuscripts which in- clude this material coming from Petrus' collection of texts (F K M Q S U b h 1 q s). The examination reveals that all is manuscripts probably derive from a common source, o-. It seems sufficient to use P and F K q for the reconstruction of the rest of the manuscripts exhibit a text which is either corrupt or otherwise tampered with or altered and thus give a less reliable picture of a. In connection with the examination of the manuscripts which contain the Addiciones as well as the text of the Alphonso edition the additional material itself (Add. 4, 5, i i and 16) is discussed separately (pp. 7o-79). Here we present a manuscript, p, which as far as Book 7 is concerned contains only the Addiciones and Chapter 14. The principles used to edit the additional material are described and the chapter ends with a separate commentary on each of the Addiciones. A report on two mss., W and g, in which the text has been edited so drastically that they have no value for reconstruction purposes (pp. 8o-82) is followed by a chapter on the important problem of the relationship of the manuscripts to the archetype (pp. 83-93). The scrutiny devotes special interest to the headings which in some mss. precede Book 7 in the form of a list of contents and which are identical with those in the text. These lists are compared with the headings within the text with a result that seems to strengthen a theory supported by other material, namely that the ms. tradition consists of two branches, one of which is represented by p while y and a form the other, derived from a common source, n. The archetype is thus reconstructed in principle by means of a comparison between p and 7r. Where y and a have different versions, the reading of the archetype was presumably the one occurring in f as well. In those places where p has one reading and n an- other it is in many cases impossible to determine on linguistic or contextual grounds which was the reading of the archetype. The chapter on the editing principles (pp. 94-99) discusses this problem and proposes reasons for using p as the basis of the edition. This chapter also includes a short survey of the rhythm of sentence endings, cursus, which reveals that cursus was probably attempted in the revelations which have been preserved in the form of letters. The introductory parts of the thesis dealing with the manuscripts naturally con- tain some material on textual criticism. A closing chapter (pp. Ioo—I I o) incorporates in addition 15 passages for examination. In four of these the archetype is assumed to have the correct rendering while in i i cases it is thought to be erroneous. Since it is unlikely that the primary codex of the Alphonso edition contained these mis- takes, the archetype was not identical with this codex.

 KUNGL. VITTERHETS HISTORIE OCH ANTIKVITETS AKADEMIEN STOCKHOLM REVELATIONES SANCTAE BIRGITTAE REVELACIONES LIB . IV EDIDIT HANS AILI 
 
 
 
 
 SANCTA BIRGITTA REVELACIONES BOOK IV EDITED BY HANS AILI 
 
 
 
 
 Published with the aid of grants from the Swedish Council for Research in the Humanities and Social Sciences AILI, H., Sancta Birgitta, Reuelaciones, Book IV 416 pp., Svenska Fornskriftsällskapet and Kungl. Vitterhets Historie och An- tikvitets Akademien, Stockholm 1992. ISBN 91-971445-2-1. This critical edition of Liber IV of the Reuelaciones of Saint Birgitta of Sweden, like its predecessors in this series, bases its text upon the readings of selected, medieval manuscripts. The text of the Editio princeps (impr. B. Ghotan, Liibeck 1491) has been superseded, particularly in those ten Revelations of Liber IV that were also incorporated by Alfonso of Jaen into Liber VIII (Liber celestis Imperatoris ad reges); in this case, the present edition presents a text that has as yet been inaccessible to non-specialist scholars. This edition also contains an Apparatus criticus, an Apparatus fontium, a Bibliography, an Introduction on the history of the manuscripts and the text, a Glossary, and Indices of grammar, literary sources, names and places. Keywords: St. Birgitta, St. Bridget, Revelation, Vadstena, Spirituality. Hans Aili, Department of Classical Languages, Stockholm University, S-106 91 STOCKHOLM, Sweden ISSN 0347-9145 ISBN 91-971745-2-1 Printed by Graphic Systems, Göteborg, Sweden 1992

 Preface The editor of a Latin work the size and complexity of the present edition invariably owes a debt of gratitude to many superiors, colleagues, and friends. My thanks are first of all due to the Royal Academy of Letters, History and Antiquities (Kungl. Vitterhets Historie och Antikvitets Akademien) and in particular to the members of its Birgitta Committee, Professors Birger Bergh, Lund, and Jan Öberg, Stock- holm, who entrusted the task of editing this book to me and who have at all times taken a lively and constructive interest in my work, aiding me in its progress. My thanks are also due to all the members of the Latin seminars of Stockholm and Lund to whom I have on various occasions submitted problematical passages for discussion. Professor Jan-Olof Tjäder, Uppsala, has read my manuscript on behalf of the Swedish Humanistic Research Council, kindly giving it its imprimatur. Mr Hugh Rodwell, M.A., M.Litt. (Cantab.), corrected and much improved my Eng- lish in the Introduction. Needless to say, such errors as may remain are entirely my own responsibility. Work on this edition of the Fourth Book of the Reuelaciones Sanctae Birgittae was begun in 1980 by Dr Anders Piltz, Lund, who collated two manuscripts, F and K, and added numerous references to Birgitta's literary sources, before relin- quishing the task to me, at the end of the same year. Since the collating of many manuscripts unavoidably necessitates revision of earlier collations, I am alone responsible for all notes on the manuscript readings reported in the apparatus criticus. I have, however, gratefully availed myself of the wide learning of Dr Piltz by incorporating all his notes of Birgitta's literary sources into my Apparatus fontium; Dr Birgit Klockars's1 references have also been taken fully into account: the Apparatus fontium thus to a great part consists of sources noted by these two scholars, as weil as (and to a lesser extent) of sources traced by myself. Financial support for the work of preparing and printing this edition has been generously given by Statens humanistisk-samhällsvetenskapliga forskningsråd (HSFR); the Institute for Classical Languages of Stockholm has provided me with a study, works of reference, and my first word-processor. Grants for the further computerisation of the text were most generously provided by Magn. Bergvalls fond and Sven och Dagmar SalUs stiftelse. Furthermore, Axel W. Ahlbergs fond, KLOCKARS (1966:255ff.) 
 
 
 
 
 8 Magn. Bergvalls fond, Fondazione Famiglia Rausing, Sven och Dagmar SalUs stiftelse, Wallenbergsstiftelsens jubileumsfond, and Stiftelsen Knut och Alice Wal- lenberg have most generously provided me with the economic means to study Birgitta manuscripts in the following libraries outside Sweden: Staatsbibliotek der Stiftung Preussischer Kulturbesitz of Berlin, Hessische Landes- und Hochschulbi- bliothek of Darmstadt, the Pierpont Morgan Library of New York, Biblioteca centrale della regione Siciliana of Palermo, the Vatican Library, Biblioteca Mar- ciana of Venice, and Österreichische Nationalbibliothek of Vienna. I would like to extend my heartfelt thanks both to the foundations enumerated and to the staff of all these libraries, where I have received much competent help in my studies. I owe a special obligation of gratitude to Dr Per Ekström of Lund University Library for all the help he has given me in conjunction with my manuscript studies at Lund. At the Royal Library of Stockholm and the Uppsala University Library, I have received much help from the staff of the Manuscript Departments. The Stockholm University Library has been my primary source of books. The Swedish Institute (Svenska institutet), by awarding me a travelling grant, made it possible for me to study the Birgitta manuscripts in Prague: my thanks are therefore due not only to the Institute but also to the staff of the Nårodni Muzeum, the Statni Knihovna and the Knihovna Metropolitny Kapitoly.  1 Introduction 1.1 The History of the Text The text of the Revelaciones of Book IV is divided into three separate parts, each with its own history of transmission. Both the exact composition of the first identifiable arrangement of the text, the so-called Liber Alfonsi, and the dating of this version and the later additions have been the subject of much debate among scholars, notably SCHOCK (1901:22f.), WESTMAN (1911:23ff.), WESSEN (1952:XVII, )(XXVIIf.), HOLLMAN (1956:28), EKWALL (1965:82ff.), and 131-TZGH (1967:17f.; 1975:13f.). UNDHAGEN, in his introduction to Reuelaciones Liber I (1978:14-37), summarises and assesses all the preceding discussion, while JöNssorm (1989:85ff.) adds new arguments with respect to dating the Revelations. In the following pr(5,cis, I mainly follow UNDHAGEN, with certain specific reservations. Briefly, it is known for certain that a number of copies of the first edition of the Revelations were in existence in 1377, when they were presented to Pope Gregory IX and to the members of the canonisation commission he had appointed. The text had by then been revised and edited by Birgitta's Spanish confessor, Alfonso Pecha de Vadaterra, ex-bishop of .1a.,n1 . After the death of Gregory IX in March, 1378, a new commission was appointed by his successor, Urban VI. The Liber Alfonsi in its first redaction apparently contained the Prologus Magist- ri Mathiae and Rev I—VII (with 130 chapters in Book IV and 109 chapters in Book VI). About the year 1380, according to UNDHAGEN's theory (1978:16ff.)', Alfonso revised this book, producing the second Alfonso Redaction, which contained Prol. M., Rev, 1—VII, Epistola Solitarii ad reges, Liber Celestis Imperatoris ad reges (= Rev. VIII), Sermo angelicus, and Quatuor oraciones. This is the text given by the Continental manuscripts, PVY BOAN . In the Liber Alfonsi, Book IV consisted of Chapters 1--130. This is clear from the Explicit following Rev. IV 130 in the manuscripts usel for this edition as weil as in Gh, which, with slight variations, state either Explicit liber quartus celestis reuelationum, or Et hic est finis quarti libri secundum Alfonsum. His lift and works have been amply discussed by JÖNSSON ( 1989). UNDHAGEN basts this view on the facts that Book VII in its Explicit is generally called ultimus liber celestis, and that Book VII is generally called fiber ultimus also in the A&P. JoNssoN's objection (1989:86 with note 19), to the effect that Alfonso in one passage in A&P (p. 375, 1. 32) himself talls the Liber celestis Imperatoris ad reges "Liber VIII", is pointless, since the reading in question, vie, is a later correction, the original reading of the manuscript being er. 
 
 
 
 
 18 Besides the material accepted by Alfonso into the textual redaction intended for the canonisation proceedings, the Birgittine corpus contained a large number of revelations, whose contents Alfonso had judged to be too controversial or too mundane to merit inclusion. This material was, however, accepted into the text corpus by later editors. Among these later inclusions are the so called Addiciones and Declaraciones, amplifying the text and commenting on it.3 The dates of the Add. and Decl. vary; the editing was done by Prior Petrus', who had returned to Sweden about 1380, seven years after the death of Birgitta. This material is therefore not to be found in the greater part of those manuscripts which have been written on the Continent. The contents of Book IV were later further amplified by yet other Revelations - one on the excellence of the angels (Rev. IV 131), four on the morals of the clergy (Tractatus ad sacerdotes, Rev. IV 132-135), and nine dealing with the importance of the return of the Papal seat to Rome (Tractatus ad summos pontifices, Rev. IV 136-144). This supplementary material was incorporated gradually and with in- dividual variations, which has given rise to two identifiable later redactions, firstly the Vadstena Redactiod , which is characterised by the presence of all the Add. and Decl. and, in Book IV, by Rev. IV 131-144, secondly the Prague Redaction, which is remarkable because of its peculiar arrangement of the order of the various books, chiefly of the Epistola Solitarii and Liber celestis Imperatoris ad reges (= Book VIII), which in this redaction are placed between Book II and Book III. Moreover, Book IV contains ten Revelations whose text was also included, with revisions, in Book VIII, the Liber celestis imperatoris ad reges. These Revelations, which will henceforth be referred to as the "geminated" or "double" Revelations are IV 1, 3, 4, 17, 45, 48, 74, 103, 104, and 105, corresponding to VIII 25, 41, 13, 15, 50, 7, 34, 26, 27, and 28 respectively. In Books II to VII there are in all twenty-four geminated revelations6 . This fact elicited various reactions among the medieval scribes and the editors of the Editio princeps; this is discussed below in Chapter 2.5. The Revelations of Book IV to a great extent betong to Birgitta's Life in Rome, after she had left Sweden in 1349. The material of this book is heterogeneous and shows no discernible traces of editorial arrangement: in the dated list of contents of Book IV, given by LUNDEN (1957 Vol. II:11-22), Rev. B = Literature: BERGH (1967:41, 44, 48ff., 89ff.); BERGH (1971:35, 40ff., 50ff., 67f., 75ff.); EKWALL (1965:121); GÖDEL (1916:28); KRAFT (1929:65, 70, 77); NORDENFALK (1961:384 f.); ROSE (1903:891f. No. 820); ScHocK (1901:22 with note 58)9, UND- HAGEN (1978:14ff., 21f., 170ff., 199); WESTMAN (1911:22 with note 2). B is a parchment manuscript, size ca. 14 by 21 cm, containing 298 folio leaves. The manuscript has probably been cut somewhat in the binding, since traces of catchwords may be observed at the very bottom of some pages. The dating of this manuscript has aroused considerable controversy, the dates assumed for its execution ranging from 1379 to ca. 1460. The former dating is the traditional one, supported by a long note written on a flyleaf pasted onto the inside cover and giving the early history of the manuscript. Since this note mentions the existence of printed editions of the Revelations, it must be assumed to have been written after the appearance of the Editio princeps in 1492". Briefly, it would appear that the manuscript was written in Rome ca. 1379, on the request of a certain "Frater Petrus de Burgundia, ordinis minorum maximus theologus"12 , from Burgundy, and not long afterwards transmitted to Maria, Duchess of Cleves13 , who gave it to the newly founded Birgittine convent of Marienboem, about the year 1460. The manuscript bears traces of damage by fire: according to a note on fol. 155R, this fire occurred in 1513. This early dating of B is accepted by ROSE and SCHUCK, but rejected with cogent arguments by WESTMAN, NORDENFALK (1961:384) AILI (1986:86 f.). ScutocK erroneously designates this manuscript Mscr. NORDENFALK assumes that the manuscript was copied at Marienboem, after the founding of this convent in 1460; UNDHAGEN, for his part, dates B to the period 1445 to 1467; if a date earlier than 1460 can be accepted for B, then it, together with another Berlin manuscript, also previously in the possession of the Marienboem convent, b, may derive from Marienwater, the mother convent of Marienboem. Since UNDHAGEN (1978:172 with note 12) appears to countenance the theory that B may have been copied from b, although he concedes that he has not compared the respective texts thoroughly, a certain amount of space may be devoted to a discussion of this problem here. UNDHAGEN'S concern is chiefly to explain why B should contain a detailed alphabetical table of contents, otherwise known only from b (=Berlin, Staatsbi- bliothek der Stiftung preuBischer Kulturbesitz, MS. theol. Lat. fol. 262 and 263), d (=Diisseldorf, Landes- und Stadtbibliothek, MS C94), Gb (=Paderborn, Erzbi- schöfliche Akademische Bibliothek, MS. Pa. 74), and Q (=Wien, Österreichische Nationalbibliothek, MS. 3920), and assumes that this index may have been copied into B from b. To me this appears rather unlikely on the following grounds. The contents of B are typical of a Birgitta manuscript containing the early Alfonsine redaction, SA, QO. In addition, it contains the alphabe- namely Prol. Matthiae, Rev. tical index mentioned above. The manuscript, like the other manuscripts of this redaction, includes no Addiciones and Declaraciones, nor Rev. IV 131-144; on the other hand, it consistently retains the 24 geminated revelations suo loco in Rev. II, III, IV, V, VI and VII. The same revelations are also written out fully in the Liber ad Reges. In b, on the other hand, Addiciones and Declaraciones are given at the end of Rev. I: 3, 13, 16, 17, 23, 28 and 32; Rev. II: 2; Rev. III: 10, 11, 12, 13, 20, 22, 33; Rev. IV: 16, 17, 23, 32, 34, 51, 52, 55, 68, 71, 81, 93, 102, 107, 113, 114, 121, 122, 125, 127 and 129; Rev. VI: 2, 5, 9, 10, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 22, 30, 31, 32, 35, 36, 39, 52, 66, 75, 98, and 102; Rev. VII: 4, 5, 11, and 16. Moreover, of those Revelations that are consistently geminated in B, the following occur only once in b: Rev. II: 6, 9 and 11 (with reference to Liber ad Reges/Book VIII 42, 33 and 37); and Rev. VI: 26 (with reference to Liber ad Reges/Book VIII 30). In Liber ad Reges, the text is written out only in the four instances just mentioned; in VIII 7, 8, 13, 15, 22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27, 28, 29, 32, 34, 35, 36, 38, 41, 44, 50 and 58 reference is instead made to the corresponding revelations in the earlier books. This is a system which I have not encountered in any other Birgitta manuscript, although it comes very close to the principle followed in the Ghotan edition, where reference is always made from Rev. VIII to the earlier books. Cf. below, ch 2.5. Now, from the presence of the Addiciones, Declaraciones and references in b, it is quite clear that B cannot in its entirety be a copy of b, and it is hardly conceivable that these discrepancies between the two manuscripts should have gone completely unnoticed if a portion of b was indeed copied into B; it is therefore more probable that the indexes in B and b derive from a common source. 
 
 
 
 
 21 On the other hand, the following observation will show that the two manuscripts may have existed side by side in the convent of Marienboem, without being very closely compared as to contents. In the note entered on the flyleaf of B, and mentioned above as a means of dating the manuscript itself, it is observed: Notandum tamen est quod in presenti libro multe alie revelationes diue birgitte facte deficiunt que cum illis inseruntur libris qui imprimuntur In quarto etenim libro deficiunt XIIII revelationes In sexto XIII. Although this note does not mention the Addiciones and Declaraciones, it nonethe- less shows that B and the printed editions had been compared, to a certain extent. The fact that a sister manuscript, now denoted b, contained a great deal of other material that does occur in the printed editions, obviously escaped the writer's notice. "Codex Falkenberg"14 appears to be the oldest manuscript used for this edition, although, in my opinion, the arrangement of the text represents a somewhat later stage than that offered by PVY BOAb; it was written in its entirety at Vadstena Abbey, by Brother Johannes Johannis Kalmarnensis (b. ca 1362, d. 1446)15. A facsimile edition of this manuscript was published by WESSN (1952, 1956) with an introduction in English (1952:XXXI—LI), where he describes the manuscript and traces its history. He dates F to after the year 1404, on the ground that this was the year when Johannes Johannis, having been ordained a deacon, could first call himself frater. This argument has not been accepted, however. Many years before, DIDERICHSEN (1935:235, 245), discussing among many other things the relative datings of F and K, had concluded that the arrangement of the supplementary material of F argued for a dating earlier than 1390, and that this manuscript thus represented the oldest known arrangement among the Vadstena manuscripts. UNDHAGEN (1978:94) corroborates DIDERICHSEN'S conclusion with the further argu- ment that the arrangement found in K is identical with that of the oldest dated Revelationes manuscript, Fb, written in 1386'. P = Palermo, Biblioteca centrale della regione siciliana (formerly Biblioteca nazio- nale), Ms. IV.G.2, cent. XIV late, fol. 58R-97V. Literature: BERGH (1967:55f., 58ff., 68f), (1971:54ff.); COLLIJN (1924,IV note 1); EKLUND (1972:28 f., 1975:35ff.); LATTANZI (1955, 1965:62 ff.); LUNDEN (1957 1:44); NORDENFALK (1961:373 ff.); SCHUCK (1901:54 note 59); UNDHAGEN (1978:150ff.); WESTMAN (1911:270). Modern scholars agree in dating this parchment manuscript of 37.5 by 26 cm, containing 209 leaves, to the years immediately preceding Birgitta's canonisation in 1391 and trace its origins to Naples. In modern times, this manuscript was first mentioned in 1771 by Salvatore Maria di Blasi, librarian to the monastery of San Martino delle Scale near Palermo, who reviewed an ancient catalogue of the manuscripts contained in this library.' The identity of P with the manuscript mentioned in this catalogue was confirmed by LATTANZI (1955), although the catalogue was missing when she wrote her paper; she added the important point that the catalogue note on this manuscript cannot have been entered before 1386. The manuscript catalogue having since been found, the identity of the two manuscripts is reaffirmed by BERGH (1967:55). NORDENFALK'S suggestion (1961:379) that P and Y (which are remarkably similar in the execution of their illuminations) might have been completed as many as five or ten years earlier than has commonly been supposed is difficult to assess: it is founded on an observation made in the typewritten description of Y in the Morgan Library, to the effect that the style of the costumes and helmets depicted date from about 1375; but this is a peculiarity which may only be regarded as a terminus ante quem non. LATTANZI (1955:10) considers the angels depicted in P to be "rigidi, legnosi, quasi privi di muscoli", a style indicative of a late period of the Naples school of illumination, and she dates P to the final decade of the 14th century. 2 " Di Blasi, S.M., "Relazione della nuova libreria del Monastero di S. BERGH (1967:37f.), argues that the textual evidence in r and V indicates that the latter may be a direct copy of the former. The dates given for the manuscripts naturally preclude the opposite hypothesis. BER(ill'S view is contested by EKLUND (1972:26f.), mainly on the strength of evidence in the text of SA, where r exhibits some ten errors not spared by V, but he also disagrees with Bi- Rui i's evaluation of the textual evidence in Rev. VII. UNDIIAGUN (1978:156), who appears not to have noticed EKLUND'S discussion on the relationspip between r and V, concurs in BERGII'S conclusions on this subject, and traces the following tentative early history 
 
 
 
 
 25 of V: r was given by Abbot Ypolitus of the monastery of San Girolamo di Quarto outside Genoa to a fellow-monk, Johannes de Alamania, who copied Rev. I, QO, Rev. II—IV for his own use, thereby creating V; the second part of r: SA and Rev. V—VIII (cf. UNDHAGEN 1960:49) was copied by another monk, Lodouicus, who wrote the Explicit to Rev. VIII, dated 1399. This tentative history is contradicted by the individual errors exhibited by r against V in the text of SA, as observed by EKLUND (1972:26 f.); the latter scholar in fact regards these two manuscripts as descended from a common exemplar. Very clear evidence, supporting BERGH'S view on the dependence of V on r, has come to light during my own collation of these two manuscripts for my projected edition of Book VIII. In r, the whole of VIII 53 has been left out by the scribe. The omission apparently has occurred in the following manner: VIII 52 ends on fol. 202V, filling out the whole page, which is the final one of its quire. The scribe has then added the first words of the Rubric of VIII 53 (Christus per sponsam) at the bottom of the page as a catchword for the next quire (fol. 203R). Unfortunately, the Rubric of VIII 54 also begins with exactly the same words. When starting to write on the first page of the new quire, the scribe apparently therefore looked up the chapter whose Incipit corresponded to the catchword, but falled to notice that he had selected VIII 54 and not, as he should have done, VIII 53. In V, VIII 53 is also completely lacking; the text of VIII 52 ends in the middle of a column and is followed by the Rubric and text of VIII 54. Noticing, as it appears, the error in the numbering of the chapters, the scribe corrected the inconsistency by re-numbering all chapters to the end of this book, which, as a consequence, has erroneous chapter numbers from ch. 53 (= VIII 54) to ch. 57 (= VIII 58). The absence of VIII 53 and the consequent re-numbering of the chapters in V can only be understood in the light of the particular circumstances surrounding the error committed by the scribe of r; hence, it is safe to conclude that V was copied — directly or indirectly — from r. This observation is most important for the present edition of Reuelaciones, Book IV, as it confirms that V may be used in the place of r as a textual witness for those Revelations that are lacking in the latter, namely Rev. I—IV. In this part of the corpus, V thus appears to be the sole surviving representative of a problematical branch of the tradition. The library of Peter Rosenberg is famous in Bohemian history; unfortu- nately, with the exception of the book by I. COLLIJN (1914), little appears to have been written on this subject in other languages than Czech and Swedish. As to the former language, references to HLAVACEK (1966:96-97, Nos. 175, 158) and NUSKA (1964:53-80) have very kindly been given me by Dr. Pavel Spunar, of the Czechoslovak Academy of Sciences, who also informed me on the probable provenance of u, from studying the notes reproduced above. Owing to the occupation of the western part of Prague by Swedish Army forces in the year 1648, plunder was brought back to Sweden by various officers; among the booty was a number of volumes from the Rosenberg library, which eventually found their way into Swedish public libraries, notably Kungliga biblioteket in Stockholm and the University library of Uppsala. Papers and books on thesc manuscripts and incunabula have been published (in the Swedish language) by COLLIJN (1905; 1907; 1926) and 0. WALDE (1911a:1f.; 1911b:80; 1916:306-333). A survey of the Birgitta manuscripts kept by Prague libraries was published by KRAFT (1926), who adds details on the history of the Rosenberg library; KRAvr failed to notice the existence of u, however.

The manuscript has been written by one, very clear and legible hand throughout, with comparati- vely few corrections. As will be clear from the apparatus criticus of the present edition, u, despite its late date of writing, gives a text which is markedly superior to that much older Prague manuscript, x; it is therefore an excellent example of the philologist's dictum: "recentiores, non deteriores". In fact, at the time when I discovered u, thanks to an almost fortuitous visit to the National Museum of Prague, I had already collated two other manuscripts of the Prague redaction, v and 1b32 , both considerably older than u. When the latter manuscript was collated by me, it turned out that x, v, and I1) not only contained nearly all the errors of u but also shared a great number of additional errors not to be found in u. The discovery of this manuscript therefore lead to a radical revision of the apparatus, where the readings of v and Ib, which I had not had the opportunity of verifying suo loco, were completely discarded and only those of x, which had been the original reason for my visiting Prague, were retained. v = Warszawa, Biblioteka Narodowa, MS. 17067, a. 14(X); cf. UNDIIAGEN (1978:X1). Ib = Stift Schlägl, Cp1 136, a. 1391; cf. NYBERG (1970), BERGET (1971:7) 32

This manuscript is described by KRAFT (1926) and UNDHAGEN Its value as a witness to the text of Book IV was considerably reduced by the finding of u, and its readings, which in most instances are also those of v and Ib, are reported here only when they agree with those of u. Gh = The Editio princeps: Revelationes S. Birgitte. Impressit B. Ghotan, Lubece 1492. The history of the printing of the Editio princeps has been traced by UNDHAGEN33 and veed only be summarised here. The editors, Brother Petrus Ingemarsson and Lay Brother Gerard, belonged to the mother foundation of the Birgittine Order, Vadstena Abbey. They set out from Vadstena on the hundredth anniversary of St. Birgitta's canonisation, October 7th, 1491, to arrange for the first printing of the Revelations, by Bartholomxus Ghotan of Liibeck. According to the postscript of Gh, the abbey fathers were responsible for the collection and arrangement of the Revelations into this volume, which was intended to be authoritative. The printed work appeared in the autumn of 1492. UNDHAGEN (1978:1-4 and passim) with further references. 
 
 
 
 
 2 The Manuscripts and their Mutual Relations 2,0 Main Corpus: PVY, BOAb, Kux, and Fq Gh The manuscripts and the Editio princeps in which the text has been handed down to us can be arranged into four different groups, held together by distinctive textual errors. In those editions of the Reuelaciones which have already been published, the editors, HOLLMAN, BERGH, EKLUND, and UNDHAGEN, have found conjunctive errors that link these four manuscript groups into two main divisions, PVY BOAb (p) and Kux Fq Gh (n)34 , descending from their archetype, the text of which can be reconstructed on the strength of the readings common to both branches of the manuscript tradition. In Book IV, also, the existence of the archetype is confirmed by the fact that all the manuscripts share obvious textual errors, which can only have been handed down through a common exemplar. These errors are discussed below in the sections on textual criticism, chs. 3.2 and 3.3. Furthermore, a small number of apparent errors, shared by the f3 manuscripts„ and another set of errors, shared by the n manuscripts, would confirm that the textual transmission of Book IV, like that of the other Revelations books, is fundamentally bifurcated. There are seventy-odd places where the reading of PVY BOAb differs from that of Kux Fq Gh, but nearly all of them must be regarded as variant readings rather than as textual errors. The sheer number of variants, shared by PVY and BOAb on the one hand and by Kux, Fq, and Gh on the other, in itself argues that there must at one time have existed two separate hyparchetypes of the text. However, only in a few instances is it possible to find errors with a certain conjunctive force. PVY BOA') as a group are only held together by the following errors. IV 22:4 deus diues factus est egenus etc.] deus factus est diues egenus etc. PVY BOAb: diues obviously serves as a predicate attribute ("God, although rich, has been made destitute"), hence the reading of is nonsensical. IV 80:6 solucionem n] solucione VY BOAb lucione P. In the full sentence, in is obviously meant to govern the accusative; hence the readings of VY BOA') and P u was not described in print or collated until the present edition. 
 
 
 
 
 33 appear erroneous, although the error — the loss of a linea nasalis — could easily occur spontaneously. IV 85:3 defendet defendit 13. Errors of verbal tense or mood cannot always be regarded as disrupting the sense of a medieval Latin text. In the Revelations there is furthermore ample evidence that the classical rules for consecutio temporum were not always strictly observed3S. Nevertheless, the context of the above instance is such as to suggest that the reading of [3 is a real error on the part of the Latin translator; hence, we may attribute a certain binding force to the error of tense here. Altogether, then, we may regard these six manuscripts, PVY BOAb, as descen- dants of a common hyparchetype, namely p. Kux Fq Gh are also bound together by shared errors: IV 7:10 confessa PVY BOAb Gh] facta confessa Kux Fq. Facta is not only superfluous but introduces an anacoluthon; it has been removed from the text of Gh, although it must have been present in its exemplars. It is possible that this was originally an archetype error, corrected in the hyparchetype. However that may be, its presence in Kux Fq can only be explained by the assumption that it was present in their common ancestor, IV 37:3 relinquentur PV BOAb relinquetur Y] relinquuntur n. This verb is the predicate of one of a series of three coordinated main clauses; since the two remaining clauses are in the future I, the tense exhibited by n is an error on a par with that adduced above for the [3 hyparchetype. IV 68:6 paciencia] paciencie n: the correct reading must be paciencia virtus "patience appears to be a virtue but is not, ostenditur et non est, quando scilicet PVY and BOA'', the reading paciencie of Kux when ...", which is the reading of and q Gh (this chapter is missing in F) gives "the virtue of patience is demonstrated but does not exist ..." which is meaningless in this context; on the other hand, the error was also easily corrected at all stages of the transmission and therefore has no very strong conjunctive force. The readings offered by Kux Fq Gh in these three passages, taken together, are a fairly strong sign of the existence of a n hyparchetype. Hence, we may on the whole conclude that the textual tradition of Book IV of the Reuelaciones is fundamentally bifurcated, one branch, dubbed being represented by Kux Fq Gh, while the other, named fl, is represented by PVY BOA": the latter branch suffers from a certain uncertainty about the exact paths of transmission of the text from the hyparchetype. 35 Cf. below, Index locutionum, s.v.  34 2.1 The p group of manuscripts The uncertainty concerning the hyparchetype is shown in several ways, discussed below. 2.1.1 The [31 group: PVY This is in many respect the most important group of manuscripts, both for under- standing the tradition of the text and for the history of art in relation to St. Birgitta. With respect to the text, V and Y separately are closely connected to the monastery of San Girolamo di Quarto sulla Riperia, where the chief redactor of the Revela- tions text, the ex-bishop Alfons() of Ja&I, spent the final years of his life.36 With respect to art history, P and Y, both of Neapolitan origins, contain illuminated initials, introducing each Revelations book, that have influenced later conceptions of the Swedish saint. This is even more true of the two full-page illuminations of Y, which alone survive to testify to the beginnings of an entire tradition of church art.37 The textual history of these three manuscripts is somewhat complicated. The latter branch will be discussed below. In the p branch, V and Y present several complications, which indicate that these two manuscripts have been the subject of collateral influences from manuscripts not belonging to this branch. Although V and Y both clearly belong to the f group of manuscripts, each of them appears separately to have undergone a process of correction. Y seems to have received collateral readings in two stages: in its first copying, when errors and variants also to be found in V (but not in P) were introduced into the text itself, secondly when Y2 painstakingly corrected the text according to a source that appears closely related to V. In one instance, however, the reading presented by Y appears to give the clue to the reading of Alfonso's original. This passage is discussed below, ch. 3.2. V presents a different picture. As BERGH has demonstrated42, this may have been a copy of the Vatican ms. r43 . EKLUND44 , examining the text of Sermo angelicus, instead finds evidence that both r and V may have descended from a common source; a conclusion contradicted by my own findings in Book VIII (see above p. 25). In Book IV, this problem is actually insoluble, since r appears to have been bound in two volumes and the first of these (containing Book IV) has been lost. The many errors to be found in ux, while K retains the correct reading, indicate that the Book IV tradition, in the case of ux, has been influenced by a manuscript closely related to K5° The conjunctive errors shared by Kux are fairly common; only a small selection is given here: IV 9:6 sequens non consciencie sue stimulos set suum carnalem affectum] sequ- ens consciencie sue affectum Kux. The omissions of non and stimulos set suum carnalem could not possibly have occurred by chance in K and ux separately, and leave no doubt that the text of Book IV has been copied from the same exemplar by the scribes of these manuscripts.
